issues.text: The correctness of the High Courts view that s. 479A has no application to offences under s. 467 and s. 467/120B and does not bar an action being taken against a witness under s. 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for such offences

issues.text: Assuming that where action could have been taken under s. 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure but was not taken by the criminal court concerned, for offences of giving false evidence in any stage of a judical proceeding or for intentional fabrication of false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, no action can be taken under s. 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, is it further correct to say that no such action under s. 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can be taken even in respect of offences of forgery or conspiracy to commit forgery?

arguments.court_reasoning: s.479A has no application to prosecution for offences other than s.193 and cognate sections

arguments.claim: The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence or for fabrication of false evidence

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any reason why this should be so. The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceedings or for fabrication of false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding.

arguments.claim: There is nothing in the section which precludes the application of any other procedure prescribed by the Code in respect of other offences

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the section which precludes the application of any other procedure prescribed by the Code in respect of other offences.

arguments.claim: In applying the principle that a special provision prevails over a general provision, the scope of the special provision must be strictly construed

anchor.surface_text: In applying the principle that a special provision prevails over a general provision, the scope of the special provision must be strictly construed in order to find out how much of the field covered by the general provision is also covered by the special provision.

arguments.claim: The acts mentioned in s.479A are punishable under s.193 IPC and cognate sections in Chapter XI

anchor.surface_text: Examining the special procedure prescribed by s. 479 A in that light, it is important to notice that the act of intentionally giving false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding and the act of fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding mentioned in s. 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure are the acts which are made punishable under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code and cognate sections in Chapter XI.

arguments.claim: If the legislature had intended that the special procedure would apply to offences other than under s.193 IPC and cognate sections it would have used clear words to that effect

anchor.surface_text: It appears clear to us therefore that it is prosecution in respect of s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code and cognate sections in Chapter XI that is dealt with under s. 479A. If the legislature had intended that the special procedure would apply to offences other than offence under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code and cognate sections in Chapter XI it would have used clear words to that effect.

arguments.claim: s.479A has no application to prosecution for offences other than under s.193 and cognate sections in Chapter XI and ss.476-479 continue to apply for other offences

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that s. 479A has no application to prosecution for offences other than an offence under s. 193 and cognate sections in Chapter XI and that as regards other offences ss. 476, 477, 478 and 479 continue to apply even after the enactment of s. 479A.

arguments.claim: action under s.476 cannot be taken if action could have been taken under s.479A but was not

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.479A prescribes special procedure only for intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence (punishable under s.193 IPC and cognate Chapter XI sections); strict construction of special provision's scope when prevailing over general (ss.476-479); no legislative intent for broader application to offences like forgery; other procedures remain available.

holdings.text: The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceedings or for fabrication of false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any reason why this should be so. The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceedings or for fabrication of false evidence for

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.479A limited to specific acts of false evidence or fabrication; nothing precludes other Code procedures for other offences; even assuming bar under s.476 for perjury where s.479A not invoked, does not extend to forgery.
